title: Does a high IQ mean someone is more intelligent? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: A high IQ is an indirect indication that you most likely have a higher intelligence than the average person. You can’t measure intelligence directly. It’s much too complex for that, as intelligence can mean a number of different things. The general consensus is that intelligence refers to a set of mental skills which are applicable to a range of tasks and where an individual with “higher” intelligence is more able to complete such tasks or to complete them faster and more efficiently than a “lower” intelligence individual. So some clever people sat down and came up with a set of tests which increase in difficulty, which need to be completed within a given time frame. Most people won’t be able to complete all the tests on a page / screen within that given timeframe, and that’s okay. It’s how far you get that counts and ultimately translates into an IQ “score”. And that’s basically what an IQ test is. It is generally assumed that a higher score on an IQ test correlates with higher overall intelligence. But you IQ score is not a direct measure of your intelligence. The important thing that many people (judging by the questions asked here on Quora) fail to understand is that your IQ score is simply a measure of how well you performed on the IQ test. It is not a direct measure of your intelligence. It also has absolutely no meaning with regards to how employable you are, whether you should be admitted to a prestigious university or whether you somehow “deserve” any sort of special treatment. Essentially, your IQ score is meaningless, and people who brag about their score are sorry figures. I mean, if all they have to brag about is an abstract score, instead of real-life achievements, than I think they should stop bragging and get a life. I don’t know my IQ score and honestly, I couldn’t care less. Question as originally answered: Does a high IQ mean intelligence?

Intelligence is a broad word. Personality is another word, unrelated to intelligence. An intelligent person with a bad personality can appear to be stupid to others. Now, I've met all types of people. People with low IQs, people with average IQs, and people with high IQs. This is what I have observed over time: People with low IQs tend to be very rude, dismissive, unempathetic and incapable of putting themselves in other people's shoesThey lack concept and depthAs for average people, I have observed that: They have a hard time thinking outside the box and they constantly need to be told what to doThey think that creativity is something related to art, not the ability to think abstractlyAs for people with high IQs I have observed that: They sometimes struggle with fitting in because they haven't found their niche yetSome of them struggle with depressionSome of them are psychopathsSome of them are narcissistsSome of them lack empathy because they are tired of being the smartest person in the roomSome of them do drugs to alleviate boredomSome of them are lazy or have unhealthy habits because they are used to the instant gratification of being smart and being able to learn things 10x faster than the average personAll of this might lead to smart people developing “poor” personalities, making them appear to be stupid in certain ways. Does a high IQ mean someone is more intelligent? Logically, spatially, verbally, and visually: yes. Wise; makes good decisions? Not necessarily.

That depends on your definition of intelligence. Each person has their own idea of what intelligence is. More often than not intelligence is an illusion, masked by soooo many variables and biases. Our beliefs affect who or what we consider to be intelligent, our understanding, political views,.... because of all of these biases it is nearly impossible to find a definition of intelligence. What it is important to remember is that while iq does not mean a person is more knowledgeable, better at school, going to earn more and it doesn't mean the person is going to act smarter, it does have some correlation with understanding.IQ is about (mostly) pattern recognition, which means people with higher IQs may have an easier time understanding certain topics because they can see the logical pattern behind it.A person with a high iq is not smarter than a normal person simply because of their iq, and assuming so is false. Regardless iq is not worthless either. Hard work beats out IQ. Which does not mean that iq is a useless measurement.  Many times people will state that iq is a bad measure of intelligence. This is true, but only because it is poorly named (intelligence quotient). This suggests that it measures the intelligence of a person, which it doesn't but rather it measures the capacity and rate of understanding. (This is very simplified!!!)

It’s a usually reliable indication one IS “smart”, though it sometimes fails in autism, where uneven cognitive processes can interfere with assumptions made in assessing FSIQ. See IQ scores not a good measure of function in autism | Spectrum | Autism Research News It’s becoming more common for those “on the spectrum” be evaluated with tests known to more accurately assess autistic performance. I have only my 1962 Army GT score, which was high enough I could join Mensa were I to apply, and an SAT verbal score (IIRC, 762) quite a bit higher than math (if I remember correctly, either 551 or 515 ). Roughly 8 years ago, at age 67, I started noticing memory problems, which led me to a local neurology clinic, where (for payment of an $800 mental health deductible) they gave me the good news – it wasn’t Alzheimer’s – and the “bad” news; I had high functioning autism. Just for grins, today I went to the Psymed site and took their autism test, deliberately ensuring that I indicated my distaste for large social gatherings and a lack of common interests with many others. “Your score indicates that you have signs of autism spectrum disorders. You may need to seek a mental health professional for further evaluation.” I’ve actually been in therapy for some time — and the therapist says I’m too intellectual. I’d rather not give that up, thank you; old age is getting to me at 75, and I’ve too much left to do.

(A2A) Yes, it only pegs raw intelligence, not what you are likely to do with it.  An IQ score is just one metric. By itself, it does not say what you are likely to learn or where you will excel, or predict how likely it is you will enjoy some success, whether you define success as earning money or achieiving a high position or having an impact of a kind that solves problems out in the world. Those details are up to you and what you do or don't choose to pursue. If you studied as many high IQs as you could find, I also suspect you would see clusters of higher highs and lower lows across the whole group, if that makes sense. Perhaps more stellar test scores, more out of box thinking, more advanced degrees, more high quality authoring or skillful problem solving etc -- but also more complicated personal issues ranging from social relations and loneliness to problems with physical and mental health. Thus, the net effect in the aggregrate might be a picture just as varied as the rest of the population, but for different reasons. From what I have seen up close, high IQ is (generally) not a ticket to a life of easy high accomplishment, but just as often leads to a life of added complication and effort.

Can you write books about the problems confronting mankind which are conversant with the language and culture of the intellectuals who will be reading your book? Are you conversant with the problems that the overall intellectual community deals with and thinks about, and can you write books that they will read and take seriously? Do you think “CONCEPTUALLY" in addition to having a broad knowledge base that includes a lot of histotical and scientific knowledge? Are you conversant in the sciences and the problems confronting the sciences? A high IQ is not necessarily required for any of this, but you can't get away with just writing about history. Your writing needs to be of an ABSTRACT and CONCEPTUAL nature, and you need to be conversant with all the issues that other intellectuals are dealing with. Can you seriously think about these and write CONCEPTUAL books that other brilliant intellectuals will be reading, criticizing, and gaining knowledge from? Someone who just sits in their apartment and thinks of things while feeling they're curious about the universe does not, thereby, demonstrate that they have what it takes to be an intellectual. Someone who knows enough about history to write books based on a lot of facts is NOT, thereby, an intellectual. Can you write books based on your own CONCEPTUAL independent thought that other intellectuals, such as Noam Chomsky or Richard Dawkins (as well as their religious equivalents) will take seriously? Can you debate with them for several hours about the problems confronting the world? Have you read all of the major philosophers? What do you know about exo-biology and astronomy? What do you know about science, as well as everything that is taking place in the sciences? Can you THINK about all this and write books that other intellectuals will read and take seriously? It is not enough to be knowledgeable. You must have profound CONCEPTUAL and ABSTRACT thinking abilities on top of a massive knowledge base. You will need to have a profound knowledge of the Ancient Greeks and their philosophy and science, in addition to profound knowledge about the modern world. You will have passed through Marxism and many of the philosophies in your thinking over time, you will have been both a THEIST and an ATHEIST at some point, and that's only the tip of the ice berg. But it is the ABSTRACT AND CONCEPTUAL nature of your thinking which distinguishes you as an intellectual, rather than just being an academic or knowledgeable person. Look at some philosophical texts, or simply books by Noam Chomsky, Thomas Sowell, Carl Sagan, Jacob Bronowsky or more recent intellectuals. Are you capable of writing those books? Would philosophers read your books and take them seriously? Could you debate with a Jordan Peterson or a Thomas Sowell for several hours and potentially win the debate? Could you go back in time and debate Hegel and Plato for several hours and stand a chance of winning the debate? and so on …

Not at all. While I am against the idea of IQ entirely, I will say that YES it does have it’s uses in determining certain aspects of intellect, but you cannot derive full intelligence from such a small pool of variables. I am what you would call an intellectual, but my IQ is only slightly above average. I read books on a lot of things and while my memory is poor, I can effectively take my knowledge and expand upon it in deeper thought once I figured out a cool memory trick. You see, unless you’re mentally handicapped, IQ is almost meaningless with no work put into it which is the case with a lot of people whom I know, but you don’t need a High IQ to be extremely smart or arguably even moderately intelligent. So no, if you invest your time wisely and dedicate yourself to your studies and/or interests, you’ll most likely come off as very smart and “intellectual”, because you are!

I think it's true. IQ test doesn't valid at all times. Because when you're in good mood, you can get high IQ score. Recently I've been reading Emotional Intelligence by Daniel Goleman (I'm interested because it's best seller even when I pay for it the cashier said that I have to pay more because the price is more expensive than before). Okay, the book gives understanding that emotional intelligence (EQ) is more important than IQ. It explains that we respond events fast using EQ, then the IQ give response after it. The book not only gives the explanation but also gives the real examples of events that happened. One of examples is father that falsely shoot his child because of thinking that there was robber in his home. If we can't use our EQ wisely, we ended up with regretting what we've done.

Yes and no. For when it comes to emotions (understanding them at a social level), spirituality, to having an amount of knowledge, no. If you are talking about how fast you learn of things and figure them out, yes (aside from kinesthetic pursuits, which more is bodily memory).. I do not have to study as hard, I do not have to read very much, and I ahead of time know the answer before most would… I figure out things through piecing them together.. As an example, I will give you this: If someone is saying you are having poor boundaries by overwhelming them and claims you are abusing them, and then they say you are overwhelming someone else, but never outright say you abused them, you can logically conclude that they would also think you are abusing the said other person. I can fill in blanks, but at more abstract levels than this.. Soduku is a good example; if a 7 is in the grid or above you in the row or further down in the row, 7 does not there belong in that grid or in that strip of line. that os how I think at a subconscious level. Another example is that I did not have to learn or read about how I attain information; I observed my own self—that I observe, think of possibility, recognize patterns and connect. I see intricacies and how things interrelate. I think outside the box— what if gnats are machines disguised as gnats, disguised so I do not think they are machines and this is a conspiracy?.. That is how I think, aside from connecting things through my observation as well as brain storming sometimes. Most people would need to spend years learning about psychology to possess of the degree I of it know, whereas I am not even yet graduated of high school and have not read much of it; just, pieced things together through analysis of my own self and others, and reading basic, basic information. I just require a lesser effort. I can piece together that a narcissist uses pride as a mask to fulfill a low self esteem; it is not something I need read, I knowing it is a maladaptive tactic, can figure that out. That is why I have such a breadth of knowledge in psych; I always fill in the blank. You’ll as an example see inmost questions even I ask on Quora, I have an explanatory second question, as if I almost already know the answer and am just looking for verification of whether or not my conclusions are correct. As an example:What causes water to spread? Is it the force of hitting the surface it falls upon, or perhaps more specifically, gravity? and Why does the brain not process nightmares the same as real life trauma, since nightmares also can feel so real? Is it because the brain is aware it is in a sleep state, or perhaps different brain parts activate?.. This is what I mean as in I fill in the blanks; I question and then look for possible explanation. That is my inherent nature. I do not need to read something to learn about it; I observe my thought (unless it is about specific facts, like for instance, the composition of a Quartz crystal. Then I will need read to attain that info).. Use logic, thinking about possibilities and observation to deduct a conclusion. I do not want to give you principles I have observed existent, and made my own system out of it, but I as an example, will figure if there is a storm nearby, and there is a fire, lightning must have struck and created fire. If someone cannot unscrew a cap, I will first try that, and if it does not work, pull upward instead (find a different way to do it). If I cannot undo a locker with a scroll set up, I will presume I put off the locker by one number and scroll each the digits up and down one than the originally intended combination. I do not need to read a system to understand how something works; I can figure it out my own self through pondering my own thought and through observation (it is hard to explain this without giving information for a book I am writing). It is hard for me to explain, but in a simple answer: I need lesser work to attain knowledge and information. Most the information I get, I discover through the self of my own; my inner logical reasoning and pondering thought. (Me enclosing furthermore examples would disclose theories and systems I have created that I have not yet copyrighted, and I have entitled briefly of them enough in answers and questions I have asked which I should not have done). Most people are not as good as identifying patterns as per say, someone with a high IQ as myself is, which thus leads them to not as readily understand things. Knowledge is different and can accumulate through repetition. You can be an equivalent in terms of success with the knowledge; that is the end result. It is a matter of possessing the knowledge, how fast you get it does not matter unless perhaps you are in timed conditions or need right on the spot understand of such (makes it beneficiary in things like psychology, law, science, writing, etc). So.. Does IQ determine success? Not necessarily. There are plentiful examples of high IQ individuals who were less than successful. There are mostly average people IQ in our society.. Most are doing fine, living a stable, bountiful life. Though perhaps, living blindly as to the dysfunctions blatant to me, in our world, and I cannot help but want rectify and for some, eradicate them. I have a high IQ, and I wouldn't say I am successful, though childhood abuse and coupled disorders from it are the reasoning as to why. Otherwise, I very much would by now, be, as even teachers had recognized and I won a state award, which this answer is not for telling, but it is in my currently pinned (also of 09–01–20, may not in future be) answer. If you want to define success by Quora, I certainly would say I am on here, successful in a degree (QPP member, more than 100 followers attained each month, made a few decently supportive friendships, documented my abuse with proof which can help in legality should I ever need of it, many answers put in the Quora Digest, etc), but other than that, no.

Yes. It is not a perfect measure by any means, but it’s the best we currently have. Of course, being very intelligent does not make you knowledgeable (a very intelligent baby will still need to learn how to talk, walk, etc), nor does it protect you from making mistakes, even really stupid ones (in fact, making mistakes is how humans learn; if you don’t make mistakes the topic is too easy for you), Being very intelligent isn’t always a boon either: our society is geared for the average brain (since most people ARE average), and very smart people can have trouble fitting in, just like for example very tall people (try finding a car if you’re 7 foot tall: a big car just means a bigger console and often even *less* room to squeeze your legs!). School is a good example where many gifted children run into trouble because the material is not suited to them. If this is you, read up on giftedness (IQ130+) from as many different sources as you can find, and see what applies to you. There’s good sides and bad sides, but as usual, knowing what the problem is is half the solution.

My guess is that the higher the intelligence, the less deceiving or tricky (astute) is the person. Then, if smart means misleading or tricky, the more intelligent is less smart. This is due to several reasons: Being misleading requires mental effort, planning and continuous tracking of deception, which is a waste of time for someone who prefers to use their time on generating abstractions or other deep thought choresThe superiorly intelligent finds simpler and more direct ways of solving problems than devising complicated liesA high intelligence concludes that any deception will inevitably backfire, so it is better to avoid itMoral issues. The superior mind evaluates how acceptable is to lead others into confusion or self detrimentGuilt awareness. One who is highly intelligent understands that any wrongdoing will make them feel remorseful some dayPascal, Newton, Einstein and most superior brains did not have a reputation of astutes. Feel free to comment on great thinkers who were famous for being astute or cunning. Answer to Does having a high IQ generally make you smart?

IQ is a measure of logical , spatial, numerical and grammatical intelligence.If you hit it big , you are logically sound , extremely analytical , highly observant and profoundly versatile.But what it cannot measure is social and emotional intelligence.I have heard , even in quora , about massively high IQ people suffering from overdose of mental vitality. They don't have the necessary emotional intelligence to handle their gifts or hard earned talent.They are socially awkward , prone to daydreaming , are brutally honest in their opinions on other people , are very arrogant to a fault , always have a desire to prove that they are better , are always bored , do not possess any ambition as their intellect can learn anything in a short amount of time.What they ought to be learning is social and emotional intelligence. They must take it as a challenge to be able to learn and experience new things. They are so many things to learn from the world and they are “ bored” after having known a few obscure concepts and mastering them.

Well, the "I" in "IQ" is for intelligence. So, the issue would be whether that type of assessment and the evaluation of such has the chops that some think.   Gardner, and others, proposed a more full look at the proper way. But, IQ does have some type of sticking power. At least, the bit dribblings on Quora seem to indicate that.  Now, if those tests were effective, could we not go observe such? Even then, we get into interpretation. And IQ, many times, goes ego (super-ego). Not all.  Unfortunately, the counter view of EQ has the wrong acronym. E for ego?  But, let's say that we say that IQers rock after a certain point (and hold our noses as we do so). Why is it that some little bit of humanity would be so endowed (there are many ways to be endowed, by the way) thus? Ah, age-old question.  My additional would be this: how can we keep those whose abilities allow them to have a very wide sphere of influence in check (oh Lord, deliver us)?

No. It does not mean as such, in Deidre Lovecky’s book a group of children scoring 194 on average on the SBL-M scored around 142 on the WISC-III, and in Yolanda Mates’ study a group of 170+ students scored 142 to 155 on WISC-R. If such discrepancies are possible, IQ is a shaky concept, some scored as high as 200 and had learning disabilities like part-to-whole and such. But Spearman’s Diminishing Marginal Returns is a statistical artefact, until tighter testing is used like deviation IQ tests, SB5, WAIS, WISC the higher IQ is very likely not unilaterally more intelligent and not even so by current deviation testing methods probably.

Thanks for the A2A request. A high score (at or above 115) on legitimate IQ tests generally means high intelligence for aspects related to academic achievement and success in employment contexts. HOWEVER, a high IQ does not guarantee that one will actually perform well in school or on the job. What is also required are many personality traits related to industriousness (working hard, consistently), perseverance (not giving up in the face of failure), sincerity, humility, sensitivity to the feelings of others and other character traits. There are many aspects of what is considered intelligent behavior which is not measured by traditional and legitimate IQ tests. IQ tests have a very specific purpose in the 20th and 21st century. I’ve written succinctly about those purposes several times already. Feel free to peruse my answers on the purpose of IQ testing.

Having a high IQ means you are intelligent, based on how researchers define it. It does not mean you are knowledgeable or wise. A simple analogy, IQ is how much processing power you have. What you do with that processor is up to the individual. I always say, I was born with a quantum computer in my head, but I never learned to operate it. Many people confuse intelligence with knowledge. They are not the same thing. In the correct situation, the high IQ individual can gain knowledge faster, and usually understand the concept instantly. This is about as simple as I can make it. I have a high IQ, but my knowledge doesn’t match.

That is an interesting question to me. I think that the answer is a resounding NO! I will get a lot of kick back on this, but I have given this a lot of thought. Genius needs to be accompanied with amazing accomplishments. And for that, one needs passion as well as intelligence. Now genius is just a word and we can attach any meaning to it that we like. But, if all it means is that someone scores highly on some test then it loses meaning when used to describe Einstein, Michelangelo, De Vinci, and many others that accomplished great and marvelous things. And, we need that word. Something else should be used to describe high IQers.

A2A Arguably yes. IQ is a measurement of intelligence; high IQ means high intelligence. For these purposes I define intelligence as the ability of the human brain to efficiently process information and to make new connections. While some argue that IQ tests are not valid (and certainly there is room to criticize what they leave out in measuring) and while intelligence must be employed, used, to be of value, IQ testing is reliable and repeatable and “valid” in testing parlance as a predictor of success in academic efforts and in occupations requiring high intellectual capacity. Philip Marks's answer to What does IQ stand for? How is it measured, and what does it really mean? Whatever IQ testing may miss, it is the best way available to measure intelligence at the moment; and the effort is 100 years old now. It is in fact a fairly well refined effort and across a broad range of tests will produce pretty much the same results.

It is analogous to asking, “Does being measured at a lofty height make you tall?” An IQ is a score from a test that is designed to measure intelligence. Your score does not “make you” anything. If a smart person is given a real IQ test, and scores high on it, that score is a measure of their intelligence, at least the kind of intelligence measured by the test. The test does not measure creativity, street smarts, or most other non-academic types of intelligence. It is entirely possible for someone to get a high IQ score, but not seem “smart” in certain circles. For example, what a group of fashion designers consider “smart” may not be captured in an IQ test.

The IQ test defined the concept of intelligence in the modern sense of reasoning ability, so yes. It can be subdivided into different forms of reasoning (verbal, visual etc) and people with the same IQ may have different amounts. People have since invented concepts such as Emotional Intelligence which might mean something but are not reasoning ability. Please note the original purpose of IQ tests was not to rate some people as inherently better than others, but to identify children who were less able to reason, so that they could receive extra teaching and get up to a satisfactory level in reading and mathematics in particular.

IQ basically measures your ability to quickly learn new information and apply patterns. It is a very narrow measurement of how smart someone is. In no field is it sufficient for success, and even in academia, hard work and ambition matter a lot more to success. However, it is useful to know for children with problems in school, because high IQ children often (paradoxically) do badly in school from boredom. Knowing that a children has a high IQ, educators can try giving them harder material when they're doing badly. Ultimately, IQ measures a specific ability, rather than being a general quantified of what would commonly be called “intelligence”.

It doesn’t make you smart but it means your smart at those things you tested well at. However, scoring low in an IQ test doesnt necessarily mean your stupid: you could have a reading disability that could greately impact the timing aspect of the test.you may be a deeper thinker that can provide deeply profound insight or solve extremely difficult problems given time, but may not be that gifted at solving high volumes of problems in the quickest time.you may be more gifted at certain aspects than someone with a genius IQ but tested lower overall.you may be gifted at other mental challenges that arent on the test at all…. and so on.I think that human intelligence covers a very broad spectrum and to think that intelligence can be well defined using a single test is kind of like claiming only those who excell at the decathelon are the only great athelites.

Basically, yea. Problem is what you put under intelligence. What IQ test say is “you learn / understand concepts faster / slower than the average person”. So if you are a fast learner, but live for your all life in the jungle with wolves, you still won’t have many academic achievements. If you have a low IQ, but put a lot of efforts despite your low learning capacities, you may end with more knowledge that someone more gifted, but lazy.

Not in the least. IQ is not a complete measure of intelligence, but if you score highly on an IQ test, you are intelligent. Maybe not wise or creative or practical, but intelligent. Anything else is virtually impossible.

Not at all, You may lack common sense for example. You may have preconceived notions put in your head by parents, schools and religion, that are not particularly smart. You may lack everyday skills that the average man has. For instance having a high IQ, doesn’t mean you know how to change a tire. Programming is difficult to learn and certain things just have to be memorized to be learned. IQ may speed this up but if you don’t know you can’t figure it out using your high IQ. Questions about high IQ’s bug me. It indicates some sense of superiority in people. People who tell you what their IQ is are rude and annoying.

I suppose it’s more fulfilling that way but what intellectual are you? Are you the the professional kind? It will help you fulfill yourself as a part of the community and much accolades, awards, and the cozy elitism of such membership will be yours. Maybe some other thing you seek. If you are a true intellectual, you enjoy the process no matter how dumb you are but what is wasted is the free spirit that should be elevated above the status climber. He is the exception, you are the rule. Much better use is made of his intellect for the professional it is but a rafinement.

Usually a high IQ implies a good level of intelligence.Exceptions are rare. The reverse is not true: a bad test does not necessarily mean a low intelligence: all kinds of circumstances can intervene (culture, sickness, lack of sleep, language, some mental difficulty, etc). High IQ is not always related to high success. And some precious gifts like creativity are not measured by IQ.

A high IQ usually means that you think differently in some way. I solve complex problems with wave functions. That is meaningless to someone who has the same IQ but solves problems using linear regression.  Some process information faster, some remember better, but the bottom line is that we think differently, not better, just different.

The words IQ and intelligence are analogous; therefore, if a person were to say have an IQ of 160, they are very intelligent. This has nothing to do with success in the world or anything else. Intelligence talks about potential and nothing else. A person with an IQ of 160 might be thrilled with working in an automobile junkyard pulling parts off of junked cars. The same person has the potential of becoming a professor of theoretical physics at a major technological college.

No. I’m a professor myself and have an IQ that has officially been tested at 2–4 standard deviations below average (I took these tests when I was 5–8, so you can possibly take that with a grain of salt). I’ve won a few awards as a professor for 5 years so far, and was a school-teacher for 5 years. I worked really hard and always looked for help - and that’s pretty much it.

It defines the ability to do IQ tests and by proxy the tasks that look like the skills captured by the IQ test. If you are looking for an indication of analytical ability then IQ may be a good proxy. If you are looking for a proxy for ALL kinds of intelligence or of the value of a person in a broader sense then IQ may be only a partial measurement.

It depends on what you mean by intelligent. Having been in contact with a lot of people with very high IQ’s, I can tell you that they are just as humans as anyone. I have a 160 IQ and I still do incredibly stupid and make very stupid decisions.

Yes… the IQ test is the standard by which we measure intelligence and has been for over a century. Like it or not the IQ test is the best measurement of IQ. If one person scores a 170 and another a 145, the 170 is by the standard more intelligent than a 145.

Seeing these answers to this question bring me to some musings I’ve had over the years. “The truly intelligent, ON A PERCENTAGE BASIS, make as many mistakes as the typical non-gifted person. They just make many, many more! But, also on a percentage basis, they make about the same amount of correct answers.” The operative phrase is, “Percentage Basis”.

I would say that in many respects it suggests that that person is very intelligent since he/she would be skilled at the use of logic, sifting of facts and recognizing patterns (basically data). However, there are other types of intelligence which are not strictly based on data and to which reason ( is not generally accepted) as applicable..

Every high I Q person I have known has seemed, compared to myself and my tiny brain, as a near genius in the wealth they have captured, the achievements they have made, and the success of their attempts at just about anything they have tried to do, that they wanted to do. Even more poignant is their avoidance of human errors routinely made by lesser intellects. I can’t imagine doing or being those things without being more intelligent than the even above average bear.
Yes. .hence the words Intelligence Quotient (IQ). It is literally what IQ stands for. .how intelligent you are, which is not to be confused with how smart you are. Those are two different things.

For a solid answer to this, you would first need to define “smart.” Personally, I would view a smart person as one who could be a functional adult in life in general (so for an example - Sheldon Cooper would not be smart), likely in one or more disciplines, and who was able to acquire new knowledge, even if it conflicted with his world schema, relatively quickly. Some of those persons have been assessed to have a high IQ, some have not. It’s not about the engine in the car: it’s how you drive it.

Thanks for the A2A. Yes, and it does not even include all forms of intelligence. How much depends on how you define intelligence. If you limit it to logical thinking, problem-solving, pattern-recognition, etc., it does a fairly good job of it. If you include the other forms of "smartness", like creativity, artistic prowess, business sense, the so-called EQ, etc., then an IQ score will be far off the mark.

Intellectual implies a high IQ plus knowledge. It derives from the word intelligent. You can be intelligent, but not well read, or intelligent with lots of knowledge. The former is not intellectual, while the latter is.

Having a high IQ doesn't make you smarter, but if you have a high IQ you have more possibilities to be smarter than others. It, generally, allows you to get and memorise concepts faster therefore it allows you to be more knowledgeable with less effort.

No. What high IQ means in its purest form is you instantly get more and more of what others miss as you are more and more higher IQ. Intelligence which usually goes hand in hand or correlates is more than just the quotient it is using wisdom, advancement, and knowledge both outer and inner world to approach your destiny with graces.

Of course. How smart will be a result of ambition or lack of it. Our smartness is directly a result of what we have been exposed to, learned, memorized, and can recollect. And that in turn will reflect—when tested— our I Q.

That depends on how you define intelligence. People with high IQ’s tend to do well on IQ tests, it’s true, but that is based upon the premise that IQ tests actually measure intelligence, which always has been and always will be up for debate.

It isn’t necessary for anyone to be wise but a person with a tangible asset, s.a. high intelligence or high IQ (which is thought to correspond with high intelligence) is better served by having some wisdom if only because their innate talent gives them greater potential for good or ill. A little wisdom might reduce the chance of them doing harm to themselves or others.

Yes, a higher IQ does very generally make you smart. Though what is colloquially considered “smart” is, of course, often more context-specific. The characteristic intuition and keen awareness that a higher IQ confers left unchecked can also bring naive realism and groupthink. Human fallibility is inescapable.

There are many kinds of IQ tests. Each test measures a specific kind of intelligence. Some people can be smart socially, find smart lies, but they are so stupid in math. Are they smart or not? you can’t affirm or deny?

To be a person of intellect you need to be able to apply your intellect, that’s all. No matter who you are, if you apply everything you’ve got you will run into the problem that exceeds your ability. When you hit that point you’ll either gather more people to solve that problem or turn to one that you might be more fruitful in pursuing. If your an intellectual you keep trying. If your not an intellectual you give up. As to what number for IQ makes you an intellectual, I’d say somewhere past three standard deviations and that person cannot help but be ruled by their intellectual horsepower :-). That’s my guess.

IQ is the abbreviation for “Intelligence Quotient”. It is a measure of intelligence. A “high IQ” indicates a high intelligence quotient, which indicates a high degree of intelligence.

It depends on what you define as smart. IQ is purely the ability to solve problems. If solving problems is your definition of smart, then yes. If memorizing an encyclopedia is what you consider smart, then no.
Yes, there is different types of intelligence like emotional intelligence, and an IQ test I do not believe can test your emotional intelligence.
